forecast.rationale: My forecast is based on a statistical assessment of the resolution criteria. A 'Yes' outcome requires only one day in the 23-day period (May 9-31) where 'tariff(s)' is absent from both front pages. Conversely, a 'No' outcome requires an unbroken 23-day streak of appearances on at least one of them. While the research indicates tariffs are a dominant news story, making the daily probability of an appearance high (estimated at ~94%), the chance of maintaining this streak for 23 days is low. The probability of an unbroken streak is approximately 25% (0.94^23), leaving a 75% chance that the streak will be broken at least once. The volatility of the news cycle, with the high potential for other major stories to emerge, makes it probable that at least one day will pass without the specific keyword appearing on both front pages. My forecast is not higher because the proposal to replace income tax with tariffs is a uniquely compelling story that could plausibly sustain coverage. It is not lower because the 'single day off' condition for a 'Yes' is a very low threshold to meet over a three-week period. I would lower the probability if the tariff debate were to escalate with daily scheduled events (e.g., congressional votes), and I would raise it if a competing major news story were to emerge.
